{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2971695,"name":"Barkın Var","username":"ExplosivesTR","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/b3f665/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-10-12T11:48:19.245Z","cooked":"

What should be the optimal battery voltage for a competition match? My team’s chargers charge them up to 13.2v but i believe that some teams charge their batteries up to 14.5v. We use the chargers that came from 2021 first choice.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-10-12T11:48:28.073Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1121,"reads":369,"readers_count":368,"score":5678.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":396564,"topic_slug":"robot-battery-maximum-voltage","display_username":"Barkın Var","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/what-voltage-do-you-charge-to/426646/13","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"What voltage do you charge to?","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":39566,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/robot-battery-maximum-voltage/396564/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":2971705,"name":"Jason Daming","username":"jdaming","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jdaming/{size}/137720_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-12T13:46:18.833Z","cooked":"

Here is a good article on battery basics

I have never seen a battery register anywhere near 14.5 on FMS. Just above 13 is fine. There are a lot more important metrics however as the article describes.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-10-12T13:46:18.833Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":17,"reads":353,"readers_count":352,"score":170.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":396564,"topic_slug":"robot-battery-maximum-voltage","display_username":"Jason Daming","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/latest/docs/hardware/hardware-basics/robot-battery.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Robot Battery Basics — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":91}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":18342,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPILib Developer (Documentation), CSA"},"post_url":"/t/robot-battery-maximum-voltage/396564/2","custom_user_title":"WPILib Developer (Documentation), CSA","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2971706,"name":"Allison Conrad","username":"scubadiv3r","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/scubadiv3r/{size}/234274_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-12T13:46:30.997Z","cooked":"

The charger you have pictured that they give out in rookie kits is, for lack of better words, a nightmare and a high priority of any team starting out should be to get a better battery charger. That charger is actually illegal per the rules as shipped, it needs to have an SB50 connector on it to be competition legal anyway. Most teams use this 3 bay charger from Andymark which charges batteries at 6A and is all around a pretty solid option. Now as far as battery voltage goes, how were you measuring your battery voltage? 14.5V for an FRC battery seems really high, I would expect a relatively new battery to sit right above 13V without a load on it, so yours doesn’t seem too low. Float voltage (or the measured voltage of a battery without anything drawing power attached) can be a little misleading, as what’s most important is the capacity of the battery (older battery, worse capacity, worse robot performance in a match).

Some other (very optional) helpful things:
Battery Beak - Measures pack V and general battery health, great for checking packs before matches

Battery Analyzer - Way more in depth of a battery tester (and therefore more expensive) but this device will actually plot your batteries capacity/time so you can tell exactly how well it’s doing. Not a necessary buy for teams, but it can be helpful

I would expect to see 14.5 volts while the battery is charging…then when you disconnect the charger, the voltage in the battery quickly tapers off to 13.2, and if you let it sit for a day, it might drop further.

Maybe you are a bit confused about what is really happening with the battery voltage?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-10-12T14:18:53.593Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":310,"readers_count":309,"score":107.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":396564,"topic_slug":"robot-battery-maximum-voltage","display_username":"Jim Forbes","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6260,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Jim Forbes 1726 Mechanical Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/robot-battery-maximum-voltage/396564/4","custom_user_title":"Jim Forbes 1726 Mechanical Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2971715,"name":"Mark Wasserman","username":"Mark_Wasserman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mark_wasserman/{size}/9677_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-12T14:33:08.704Z","cooked":"

The 14.5V (it’s more accurate to say 14ish) number comes from charging algorithms of “smart chargers”. That’s the magic voltage level of which you watch the current fall and you know you’re at the end of absorption then they jump to float or to open. A really healthy (chemically speaking) battery, sitting at rest should be just below 13V. 12.7V-12.9V is the natural voltage potential of a typical lead acid. We monitor both current and voltage during charge but that is mostly an OCD issue with us. I got to know where the electrons are going! The green light on most reputable chargers is the judge and jury most of the time.

image774×606 61 KB

This thread will end up with a lot of recommended chargers listed and they will all be good and FRC legal. We currently use a NoCo charger that appears to be discontinued. We also use the Andymark charger but we just watch the green light with that one.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-10-12T14:33:08.704Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":11,"reads":301,"readers_count":300,"score":130.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":396564,"topic_slug":"robot-battery-maximum-voltage","display_username":"Mark Wasserman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/f/9/f93f83c92eb71dca193fde30ee6eb41415b97ad8.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30473,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Not fast swerve, but good swerve driven quickly"},"post_url":"/t/robot-battery-maximum-voltage/396564/5","custom_user_title":"Not fast swerve, but good swerve driven quickly","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2971743,"name":"Ender Wiggin","username":"EnDeR_WiGGiN","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/cdc98d/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-10-12T16:56:18.192Z","cooked":"

You should try and match what the manufacture’s spec is for the battery. You will gain a different experience depending on your charger. There are tons of lead-acid chargers out there and a lot of them have their own special sauce. There is defiantly an advantage to a lead-acid charger that uses a higher voltage, especially when charging in between matches. ES17-12

These voltages are just charge voltage. I would not expect the battery to be at those votlages when taken off the charger. Like others have said it should be around 13.2-13.5 right off the charger.

Here are some examples of the variations in chargers.
https://earthxbatteries.com/our-batteries/battery-charging

Key things to note:

  • de-sulfate mode/deep conditioning mode/pulse mode voltage
  • maintenance mode/float charge voltage
  • Charge current
  • Charge Voltage

I would just use what a team you trust recommends.

Here are some FRC files i found in a quick google search:
771 Best Battery Practices (2011)

List of battery chargers

Old post on the Subject

EarthX Lithium Batteries - OEM LIthium Batteries for All Motor Sports","clicks":5},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/battery-chargers/111323","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Battery Chargers","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41570,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/robot-battery-maximum-voltage/396564/6","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2971775,"name":"Barkın Var","username":"ExplosivesTR","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/b3f665/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-10-12T18:33:33.292Z","cooked":"

Thanks for all the repliles,
As I understand from all of the replies I think it is tottaly normal for battery to be at that voltage. Also, we crimped sb50 connectors to the chargers. Since my team is in Turkey we don’t have any suuplier that sells those fancy chargers. I believe that best choice for us to use this charger. We have 4 chargers and planning to make a battery cart with them. I hope that it will not be a fire hazzard since they are not high quality.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-10-12T18:33:33.292Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":241,"readers_count":240,"score":73.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":396564,"topic_slug":"robot-battery-maximum-voltage","display_username":"Barkın Var","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":39566,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/robot-battery-maximum-voltage/396564/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"hugs","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2972314,"name":"Allen Nuttle","username":"nuttle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuttle/{size}/124105_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-17T19:10:48.920Z","cooked":"

These batteries are composed of several cells (typically 6 for FRC batteries), in series. Each cell has a voltage which has to do with the electrochemistry of the materials. If you apply too high a voltage, “Overcharging with high charging voltages generates oxygen and hydrogen gas by electrolysis of water, which bubbles out and is lost. The design of some types of lead-acid battery allows the electrolyte level to be inspected and topped up with pure water to replace any that has been lost this way.” (Source Wikipedia)

You can measure the open-circuit voltage (no current is flowing, only a tiny amount used for taking the measurement). A good battery charger does this, and also monitors charging current and uses both of these to manage charging. The exact values to look for really depend on the specifications for the specific battery you are using. These values can also tell you something about the state of the battery.

Generally, the chargers marketed for FRC use are pretty good choices, if you can get the same thing, even if this is without the SB50 connector (which is easy enough to add).

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-10-17T19:11:28.300Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":208,"readers_count":207,"score":46.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":396564,"topic_slug":"robot-battery-maximum-voltage","display_username":"Allen Nuttle","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lead%E2%80%93acid_battery","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Lead–acid battery - Wikipedia","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14283,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/robot-battery-maximum-voltage/396564/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2979199,"name":"Al Skierkiewicz Learn Something New, Every Day!","username":"Al_Skierkiewicz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/al_skierkiewicz/{size}/110877_2.png","created_at":"2021-11-30T22:52:50.361Z","cooked":"

OK, Sorry to come to the party late but I need to add to this discussion.

  1. The pictured charger above is not a nightmare. It is a simple smart charger that needs to have the gator clips replaced with SB50. For those teams that have not done this before, stripping the wire insulation at least two inches and then folding the bare wire in half, twice (four times the original diameter) will give you sufficient diameter to crimp in the SB50 contacts. I use this charger on several different types of SLA batteries of various sizes and it works great. I added standard Anderson Power 35 amp connectors as that is what i use around my ham shack.
  2. Any battery will read a higher voltage than stated when removed from the charger after charging has completed. How high that voltage you read will be a function of the battery and the impedance of the meter you use to measure voltage as well as the method of charge used. Simple constant voltage chargers may give you a reading as high as 15 volts. However, measuring voltage under load, will show a voltage much closer to 12 volts as specified by the manufacturer.
  3. Measuring terminal voltage on a battery (no load) is not an indication of the state of the battery. Many teams who use this method have found that the battery does not last a full match. As pointed out above, FRC batteries have six cells, each of which have multiple plates wired in parallel. If one (or more) of those plates detaches from the other plates in the cell, it will still read 12 volts but will have a reduced capacity.
  4. FRC batteries are a particular type of SLA (Sealed Lead Acid) battery where the acid solution is held in a fiberglass mat between plates of lead. High charge currents or high discharge currents can cause the water in this solution to turn to vapor temporarily but it will be reabsorbed by the mat rather quickly.
  5. Using a high voltage to charge these batteries can result in arcing internal to the battery which cause shorts to develop between the plates which will lead to self discharge of the battery cell. This is evident by terminal voltage dropping by 2 volts when the cell can no longer develop any current.
  6. To be sure your batteries are healthy, I recommend at least annual tests of your batteries using a programmable device like the West Mountain Radio CBA-IV. These are available from the manufacturer or from Andy Mark. I run tests at 7.5 amps to 10.5 volts which will duplicate the manufacturer’s published curves for discharge and will show an amp hour rating. I have found that batteries that are tested this way and report an amp hour rating higher than 12 AH will survive FRC matches. At 7.5 amps the test will take about 2 hours. You may run the test at 1 amp but it will take close to 18 hours. The result will report near the 18 amp hour rating for FRC batteries.
  7. The Cross The Road Electronics battery tester will give you a quick check on battery as it tests the battery under two different load values and then displays a result. Many teams use this right before a match to be sure that the battery is charged.
","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-11-30T22:52:50.361Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":143,"readers_count":142,"score":68.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":396564,"topic_slug":"robot-battery-maximum-voltage","display_username":"Al Skierkiewicz Learn Something New, Every Day!","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":121,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Chief Robot Inspector Learn Something New, Ever Day!"},"post_url":"/t/robot-battery-maximum-voltage/396564/9","custom_user_title":"Chief Robot Inspector Learn Something New, Ever Day!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2979204,"name":"Nate Laverdure (he/him)","username":"Nate_Laverdure","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nate_laverdure/{size}/134005_2.png","created_at":"2021-11-30T23:24:49.957Z","cooked":"
Al_Skierkiewicz:

It is a simple smart charger that needs to have the gator clips replaced with SB50. For those teams that have not done this before, stripping the wire insulation at least two inches and then folding the bare wire in half, twice (four times the original diameter) will give you sufficient diameter to crimp in the SB50 contacts.

Good stuff Al.

One small comment: as recommended by Spectrum’s guide, you can use the TE Connectivity sample voucher program to get FREE 10-12awg contacts compatible with the SB50.

The other trick I’ve used with chargers is to build SB50 to PP45 adapter cables with 10 AWG and then use smaller gauge contacts (e.g. PP15) for the charger cable, which avoids the need to fold over the wires as many times. (PP45 and PP15 housings are identical so the two can connect)

FWIW, when I’ve put an SB50 onto a charger with smaller wires (essentially all of these have smaller wires than used on a robot, as the charging currents are much lower than the maximum discharge current on a robot), I’ve used terminals made for smaller wires (5953-BK).

image1500×446 153 KB

image1490×524 180 KB

Here’s a link to a datasheet with a lot more on these connectors. The dust cover is also not a bad idea. When going this route, you can choose from quite a few colors.
